conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to trace the paths of the liquids as they flow down through the baffles and determine which containers (E, F, or G) they will end up in.
The liquid starts flowing from points A, B, C, and D.
The black liquid flows down over the black baffle and then turns right, following the white baffle. It then continues downward, avoiding other baffles to reach the bottom left area.
The black liquid ends up in container E.
The green liquid flows down over the brown baffle and then turns right, following the purple baffle. It then continues downward, avoiding other baffles to reach the middle area.
The green liquid ends up in container F.
The pink liquid flows down over the purple baffle and then turns right, following the orange baffle. It then continues downward, avoiding other baffles to reach the bottom right area.
The pink liquid ends up in container G.
The yellow liquid flows down over the yellow baffle and then turns right, following the blue baffle. It then continues downward, avoiding other baffles to reach the bottom right area.
The yellow liquid ends up in container G.
The second image shows the initial flow patterns which are consistent with our tracing.
The third image shows the combined flow patterns where the liquids merge and continue their paths as described above.
Liquid from A flows into container E.
Liquid from B flows into container F.
Liquids from C and D flow into container G.
